lg.l: naṟumalark kōtaiyu nampiyu naṭuṅkineṟiyi ṉīṅkiyōr nīrala kūṟiṉum
At the break of dawn in which Āditya (literally, the eyes of the sky) have not [yet] opened,
As the white moon in the sky in which stars shine goes away,
As the night at the end of the day, which were dark like rainclouds,
- the ripening/ancient Karma being driven forth - opened [its] insides,
Having crossed a tall entrance with a tall door
Of excellence that is befitting, that was executed [well] with a lock,
Around which the male ram, the male yak and the goose with pure feathers
Having crossed, circumambulating the temple of the sapphire-hued one,
Who rested [in] a knowing sleeping upon a snake that was adorned [and] shined,
Having gone to all the seven temples of Indra in which
superhuman beings proclaimed the sacred word as Dharmic beings
Under the beautiful, shining shade of the Bodhi with green leaves
That was high with five measures,
At the place/platform nearby which stood [as] five types,
Where great people who the way of truth,
[With] the principles in of knowing restraint,
Having renounced meat-foods, having left sorrow
By means of unfailing vows/unlying vows thronged
At [that] meeting place as high as the sky,
In which [those intersections] mixed together, having come,
[Under] the rich shade that shines with beauty,
And the festival of the tall chariot!’,
Raised seat [of worship] that shines with brightness
That was placed together by the ascetics of the world,
Being like a great river that originated [in] the mountains,
Descending together into the backwaters [that were] the world,
Having gone to the outer wall of a good arbour of trees
In which many blossoms were piled up,
Where the wind [from] the Malaya region
Paid [tribute] to the [Cōḻa] king along with
The desirable summer [season]/the summer of Kāma,
The man without [even] a fraction [= form],
Having crossed the end of entrance [= delta] of the mouth
Of the Kāviri [with] a big path, of a cool season/weather
Entering a flower grove on the big northern shore
Of the Kāviri of rich floods, having taken the western direction,
Having reached the grove [with] flowering trees [at]
The resting place of Kavunti, [they] crossing that grove,
[She], despairing with [her] waist [like] a broken creeper,
[She with] fragrant, abundant tresses, sighing several short [breaths],
[Kaṇṇaki] asking, ‘Where could be the ancient town of Maturai’
With unaged speech, so that [her] thorn[-like] teeth shine,
It is a further six-five leagues from our land.’
Having seen the mother Kāvunti who stayed inside the quarter
Along with her with honey-sweet words, worshipping [her] feet,
[Kāvunti] saying, ‘you possess a [shapely] form, a [good] family,
Superior, great customs, and the austerities that do not deviate
From the sacred word of the great man.
The way of thinking in this way, having left behind [everything]
[Kōvalaṉ saying], ‘There is no response, oh you of great tapas!
I am one who desires the wealth [within] the boundaries
Of the ancient town of Maturai. These small, ankleted feet
Will not be able to endure the enmity of pebbles.
It is difficult to cross the lands and waters
Who could know [if] her condition enables her [to walk on]?
[Kāvunti said], ‘You who do not stay - it is not right [for you]
[Kōvalaṉ], worshipping and praising Mother Kāvunti who said,
‘Because I am one who possesses a heart that has agreed [with you],
I too will come to faultless Maturai in the good land of southern Tamiḻ,
In order to praise he who knows having heard words of Dharma
Who have abandoned words of valour [= of warriors and killing].
[Kōvalaṉ] saying, ‘Oh venerable one! If you indeed are so gracious, I have ended the misery
Kōvalaṉ, look! There are many things on this path
Who does not bear the colour (i.e., brightness) of the sun,
If we say we shall set out to a grove dense with flowers
A false comparment [= trap] having been made
Out of a pit that was dug out by a bulbous root
[Under] branches that are filled with Campaka [flowers]
From whom pollen [i.e., petals] slips down [covering the pit]
Will show, if it indeed does show,
To those people who are not guarded.
The enmity of the ripe, honey[-like] fruit [jackfruit]
Will dash, if it indeed dashes, against
Those who cross, having stepped away [from the path]
Towards the faded bits of flowers that have come apart
In the grove in which turmeric and ginger mingle,
The pebbles [= seeds] of the jackfruit with a red pulp
Oh, beloved husband of the young woman with carp-like, long eyes!
If we say we will set out to the paddy fields,
If the Vāḷai fish with long backs in the fields
That were captured by otters, having chased fighting carps
In tanks over there that emit the fragrance of flowers,
Big beehives that were woven into sugarcane [shoots],
Will pollute the pure waters of the pond
Having reached a loss of discernment,
It will be [suddenly] agreeable to take,
Drawing out the water in the palm of the hand.
From the suffering of going on the path
In the expanse in which groups of
Spotted and striped bees come together
With the buds of lilies that were placed by harvesters,
Without knowing [this], the placing of the foot over there
In the path at the shore [where the sand has] settled,
With splashing waters, the walking with old/fated feet
Upon spotted, eminent crabs and snails,
It is not feasible to endure the distress that puts one down,
Apart from [in the case of] the paddy fields and groves.
Thre is no path anywhere that lies nearby.
Oh you with a curly, dark hair-tuft!
Beware, not coming near each of those [aforementioned] things,
Her for whom you burn [= whom you desire].’
a faultless begging bowl, a cloth upon the shoulder
And a peacock feather in the hand,
Saying, ‘May god who is the wealth [of righteous] words
[Thus], they set out on the way
That was of an excellence that was devoid of defects.
Whether the black one (saturn) begins to smoke,
Whether a comet appears, or whether
Venus with expanding rays sets out towards the south,
As a rain from fully pregnant clouds shower wealth
Along with thunder with a harsh voice
At an ascent [from] being pushed [by] the wind;
At the mouth to which the new waters of Kāviri come fast,
Which squeezes together the outlets of ponds/becomes an estuary,
With many rich, rare articles that were born
In the western mountain, the fertility of the sea rivaling [it],
Besides [this] sound that sounds far beyond breaks,/that sounds beyond the irrigation channel,
At the place surrounded by paddy fields, red rice [and] sugarcane
To which the sounding of the water trough, the water lift,
the lifting [device] with an increasing sound
And the baling basket with high water do not go,
In the forest with fresh flowers [and] tanks [with] lotuses,
And the thronging calls of many different [birds] that spread
The water fowl, the wader with an intense call,
The goose with red legs, the stork with green legs,
The forest fowl, the crow the colour of water,
The common snipe, the slowly moving [bird],
Like the frontier of a king victorious in war,
As the unripe fruit of red paddy [like] yaktail fans/of the Kavari variety
Of the rich, plentiful, [forever] young food[-stores] whose rope was loosened,
While the buffaloes with red eyes [and] unwashed pelt [on their] bodies
Who sunk into, having entered the unploughed, fine slush, rubbed their plentiful backs [on it],
Apart from the sound that roared together continuously, in which
Workers with black hands and threshers come together,
And the beat/songs of newness/feasting that strong toddy destroyed,
Of status people with few words [with] red, carp[-like] long eyes
Having appeared so that they are distinct/majestic
In the guise of playing in slush/with toddy/in sandal paste
Having pressed fragrant things/fibre [= stem of flowers]
Removing scented blossoms [of the previous day/from the field],
Touching the shoulders with bracelets [and] bangles [and] the body/breasts,
And the auspicious festival/song of the plough
Of those who stood with [their] plough,
Having worn blossoms whose shining ears were linked together
Having mixed together Harialli grass from rich creepers and waterlillies
As those who praised, like those who could break rocks, worshipped [with] hands,
And the song of the drawing up (= harvesting) of paddy
[From] the big field that those who heaped the stems
Having cut [them], subject the bulls [for] the cut crops to,
And the joyful sound of the cylindrical Muḻavu drum
With clear[-sounding] Kiṇai drums lifted with elation,
Having heard the waters of the great river on the settled shores,
With keen hearts, they [the travellers] did not feel fatigue.
Apart from the seat of those of the auspicious Vedas
Who appeared as eminent as the mountains swarmed by clouds
Having covered the storeyed houses whose seats were high everywhere
In kitchens/stoves in which fire glitters breathes into the embryo of the rain
Along with the victory of the strong one [Coḻa king]
[With] a chariot [with] a tiger on it/[made of] deerskin,
[The travellers], having spread along the smoke
From the sugarcane pressing room of boiling [= foaming]
Of those who beg, the stronghold of those who protect,
And the town of ancient victory [with] those who make grow
With the plough [= farmers], [belonging to] the son
Having seen [these things] along with the country
That was interspersed with villages that appeared
In the mountains amongst the clouded sky,
Being those who did not cross further than one Kāvatam,
Having stayed for many days, on one day - the day of going,
Being very distinct in Srirangam that disappears behind the river,
They left the Paṭṭiṉam side [of Pukār for] one side [of the country]
fragrant with flowers in which the celestials stayed, in the mountainside
In which trees that wore bending bamboo were dense.
As Cāraṇar proclaimed Dharma of the unchanging truth
Of the excellence of the great son [Mahavira],
Having deigned to be seated on a shining bright raised seat
That was placed by many Lord with great names that did not leave [him],
They [Kaṇṇaki and Kōvalaṉ] fell to [his] feet
Along with Kavunti who knew [him as soon as she] saw [him],
Saying ‘My [our] ancient Karma [from] former [lives] be ruined’.
Even though he was one who knew the [through] lamp of the mind
Of the shining principles, the reason for [them] having come,
Because he is warrior who repelled desire and hatred
So that they are distant, did not take [to being] distressed.
Saying, ‘Kāvunti of very great superiority! Look!
The strong Karma that feeds [one’s destiny]
Will not be destroyed when one says ‘be destroyed!’
Like a seed that has been placed, when it sticks, Confronting [you], Reaching [you], it is impossible
To even eradicate. Like a fire that is placed
In a long open space [exposed to] fast winds,
The living beings will not stay together with the body.
Apart from if one has the light of Vedas that were uttered
[With] shining brightness [of] he of the knowledge,
He of Dharma, he who transgressed the limits of knowledge,
He who was close [to all], he who vanquished,
The first one for Dharma, the head, he of the Dharma,
He of the essence, the pure one, the ancient one,
The one who proclaims [truth], he who destroys anger,
the Lord the leader of (?)Civakati, the supreme being,
The one of good qualities(?), the light in the [world] beyond,
He of the principles, he of [excellent] restraint, the wanderer,
The reason [behind everything], the siddha, the great one,
The superior, glittering light, the Lord, the elder/relative,
He of naturally [good] qualities, our king,
He of fame that is not deficient, the king of big qualities,
He who causes prosperity, the supreme lord,
He who produced the components [of treatises], the Arhat,
The gracious sage, The one who did [good? things],
The one with eight qualities, the celestial one [of]
The ancient wealth that cannot be divided,
[And] the first one of the Vedas,
[You are] those who are trapped in a room
Having heard the truthful words of Cāraṇar,
Kāvunti, foremost in penance, having taken her hands
Upon her head, saying, ‘The inside of my ears
Will not open, except for the sacred words of knowledge
That were uttered by him who extinguished the three [flames].
My tongue will not speak, except for the 1008 names
Of him who vanquished Kāmaṉ. My eyes will not see,
Even if [I could] see [them] in [my] hand,
Except the pair of feet of him who vanquished the five [senses].
My meaningless body will not join on [this] earth, apart from
To the sacred body of he who wore grace [and] Dharma.
My two hands, having join, will not pray in one way/will not join as one
Apart from for he who is knowledgeable to [even] Arhats and him of Dharma.
My the top of my head will not bear ornaments apart from
The flower-feet of he who walked upon flowers.
Reciting again and again, my mind will not move towards [anything]
Apart from to the divine word of endless bliss.’
As [she] praised his musical words [in such a way],
The great one of penance who agreed, having risen high, being elevated,
[Thus] leaving [behind] one, whole, long [stretch of] earth,
Saying, ‘May the fetters that bring about birth/existence be lost [for] Kavunti’,
Those whose path is the sky worshipping [him],
those who humbled [themselves by worshipping, returning [to their journey],
Saying, ‘may the fetters be cut away’, going to a long ghat adorned with water
From the big river Kāviri [with] flower-groves adorned by the rainy seasons,
The lady, the husband and the great lady of penance having reached
The southern shore of a faultless marketplace, when being in a flowering grove
As those who lay [in rest], surrounded by buds, a strange/new lady,
Along with a man with poor [= unrefined] words, [being] those who went
As those who crossed the flowering grove in which pollen blooms,
Asking, ‘[They] are like Kāma [and his] wife. Who are these, [being] like this?’
Saying, ‘We must know right away’, while asking, ‘Who are these who chanced upon
The path along with you of the penance, [with] a thin body [that] eats
‘You do not see [that they are] my children, [with] human [= normal] bodies.
Leave [their] proximity [= don’t come close]. They are tired [from] travelling.’
[They] saying, Have you learned that [even] those of the same stomach
Are fated to a life of togetherness?’ Having heard [these] fiery words,
Covering the ears, Kaṇṇaki trembling before [her] beloved man, [Kavunti saying]
‘It seems these people deride my [girl who is like] a flower garland.
May they become old jackals in a forest with thorns.’ [Such was]
The curse that gave repentance, placed by Kavunti.
Since it was binding, they did not know that it had [already] happened.
Having heard the howling call of the long voice of the short jackal,
The [lady like] a garland of fragrant blossoms and [her] trusted [husband] shivering,
[Kaṇṇaki and Kōvalaṉ] saying, even if those who deviate from the path
Say unbecoming things, it is necessary [for us] to know that it was unintentional.
Oh you have perform penance, would you tell [us] the time of salvation
For those who deviated [from good morals] before your holiness?’ [She] saying,
‘Those who possess a birth of sin, standing with ignorance,
Having stayed [at] one side [of] the Nocci [growths near] Uṟaiyūr,
After enduring the pain of affliction [for] twelve moons,
May they obtain their previous forms in this way’.
Having released the curse, mother Kāvunti of the great excellence of penance,
the wife [Kaṇṇaki] and the husband, entered with desire The outskirts of [the city of] the rooster [Uṟaiyūr]
that ruined in a previous battle the elephant with winnow[-like] ears.

entry.def: to open the eyes from sleep
